column1: alchemy 160967064137 "2017-05-23 01:00:19 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/160967064137 "adhd-n-ib: When scheduling long term projects
column2: break work down into time sections instead of goals. (ie â€œI will work for one hourâ€ instead of â€œI will finish 3 pages of my paper â€). Breaking things down into time sections makes them less overwhelming and easier to start because you know exactly what is expected of you. It a lot easier to say
column3: â€ I will concentrate for 45 minutes todayâ€ instead of â€œI will finish my poster today which could take me anywhere from 5 minutes to 3 hours.â€ Â Even people with ADHD can have a perfectionist streak and sometimes this lead us to thinkÂ â€œWell Iâ€™m not going to be able to finish it so I may as well not start it at all.â€ Breaking things down into time sections prevents this and you may even be surprised with how much work you can accomplish in a few hours. " False text

column36: and powersâ€“ are typically interpreted to remain unseen and work on the spiritual plane

column41: and guardians who take on the form of man in order to serve and aide them. almost every mention of angelic messengers or apparitions in the bible is an angel of the third choir.Â  (side note: the only angels not accounted for in the celestial hierarchy are the nephilim: the fallen ones who had children by humans

column70: the terror that fills us when weâ€™re approached by something we have no capacity to understand. numinous dread is akin to what makes people quiver at the thought of ghosts

column73: to the point that humans are bowled over by the merest whiff of their presence? itâ€™s why angels who appear human but still frighten people is such an underrated concept. you know the phraseÂ â€œevery angel is terrifyingâ€? the author

column1: alchemy 160892343239 "2017-05-21 01:34:05 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/160892343239 "harboua: When we look at the first 15 years of the 21st century
column2: the most defining moment in black Americaâ€™s relationship to its country isnâ€™t Election Day 2008; itâ€™s Hurricane Katrina. The events of the storm and its aftermath sparked a profound shift among black Americans toward racial pessimism that persists to today
column3: even with Barack Obama in the White House. Black collective memory of Hurricane Katrina
column4: as much as anything else
column5: informs the present movement against police violence
column6: â€œBlack Lives Matter.â€ Among the first images of New Orleans after the storm were shots of low-income black Americans
column7: stranded and desperate to escape the floods and debris. In the narrow sense
column8: they were there because the cityâ€™s evacuation planâ€”which didnâ€™t account for massive traffic out of the regionâ€”fell apart. Rather than bring remaining New Orleansians out
column9: officials sent them to the Superdome and the convention center
column10: which were quickly overcrowded and undersupplied. In a much broader sense
column12: they were there because in a city defined by decades of poverty
column15: poor and working-class blacks (including the elderly
column16: and children) would largely shoulder the burden of the storm. To black Americans around the country

column1: alchemy 159909449674 "2017-04-23 19:22:23 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/159909449674 "erikadprice:  In segment #1
column2: former Congressional staffer Zahir Janmohamed provides the following tips for engaging with your congressperson: 1. Do not prioritize online petitions. Even if a petition has 10
column3: 000 signatures
column4: most Congressional offices only count it as 1 piece of correspondence. 2. Snail mail gets noticed. 3. Hand-written notes get read. Reps themselves use handwritten notes to communicate high-priority messages to each other. 4. Calls do help. It is better to call a home office (in the Repâ€™s state) than their DC office. 5. Follow up on calls and letters. This one was new to me! If you sent a letter or called in
column5: check back a few weeks later and ask if the Congressperson is going to respond. 6. Make the rep afraid of consequences. Iâ€™m not talking empty or violent threats - tell the Rep they have lost your vote or donation. 7. Choose specific issues and call or write about them on a regular basis. Start small with one thing that matters to you. 8. Make it personal. If you can
column6: connect the issue to a personal example. Talk about your feelings and concerns from the heart
column7: if you can. Facts or speaking from a script is fine if thatâ€™s what you have in you. 9. If you can
column10: and phone number in your correspondences. This communicates that you are in a Repâ€™s district and that you are serious

column1: alchemy 159167568123 "2017-04-03 23:00:06 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/159167568123 "wocinsolidarity: Whenever I come into a new space
column2: thereâ€™s always a sense of nervousness and anticipation. From the time I was small and up until now
column3: I was painfully shy in new settings
column4: took time to come out of my shell
column5: and struggled to relate to other folks my age. Finding community that looked like me was even more challenging
column6: which made finally finding it that much more meaningful. I remember the excitement of entering spaces with activists
column7: artists
column10: etc. after a lifetime of not seeing myself reflected anywhere else. I came to realize that much of my earlier silence and shyness came from not being allowed to bring all of myself where I went
column11: but when I discovered sacred community
column12: walls slowly began to come down. I have connected with fierce activists and chosen family in whose presence I am made better. Like most relationships worth having
column13: being in community is not always (or even often) easy. In my circle are people who challenge me to grow
column14: who will collect me when I need to be collected
column15: who expand my political and world views
column16: and who actively live the principles of love and tenderness. (In other words
column17: #squadgoals). â€œTendernessâ€ is something I write about a lot because Iâ€™ve always been called tender or hyper-sensitive
column18: and up until recently I wanted very badly to change that part of myself. Tenderness is often seen as frailty and as a weakness
column19: especially in the violently oppressive context we live in
column20: but when it comes to building true and sustainable communities of oppressed people
column21: it is a virtue. Tenderness isnâ€™t just a state of how we react or donâ€™t react to what people say/do to us â€“ itâ€™s about how we choose to treat other people. And that starts with how we treat ourselves. " False link

column1: alchemy 157800107447 "2017-02-28 00:40:19 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/157800107447 "bigfatscience:  A recent study (Lipson & Sonneville
column2: 2017) examined 9713 students from 12 different colleges and found that body weight was the most consistent predictor of eating disorder symptoms. Students with a BMI in the â€œoverweightâ€ or â€œobeseâ€ range were at the highest risk and students with a BMI in the â€œunderweightâ€ range were surprisingly at the lowest riskâ€¦ A 2013 article by Sim et al. that I wrote about in an earlier post found that eating disorder symptoms in adolescents with a weight history in the â€œoverweightâ€ or â€œobeseâ€ range not only were under-diagnosed
column3: but symptoms were actually encouraged by medical professionals who congratulated these patients for losing weightâ€¦   Eating disorder prevention and intervention efforts are often targeted at people in the â€œunderweightâ€ range while people categorized as â€œoverweightâ€ or â€œobeseâ€ are targeted for weight loss interventions. Fat people are told to diet
column4: even though dieting is one of the strongest predictors for both development of eating disorders and weight gain. Isnâ€™t it time we stopped prescribing behaviors to people at higher weights that are diagnosed as eating disorder symptoms in people at lower weights? Food restriction

column1: alchemy 156376129031 "2017-01-26 00:30:27 GMT" http://alchemy.tumblr.com/post/156376129031 "riotrite:  robertcmmacgregor:  Many believe that poor people deserve to be poor because theyâ€™re lazy. As Speaker John Boehner has said
column2: the poor have a notion that â€œI really donâ€™t have to work. I donâ€™t really want to do this. I think Iâ€™d rather just sit around.â€ In  reality
column3: a large and growing share of the nationâ€™s poor work full time  â€“ sometimes sixty or more hours a week â€“ yet still donâ€™t earn enough  to lift themselves and their families out of poverty.   Itâ€™s also commonly believed
column4: especially among Republicans
column5: that the rich deserve their wealth because they work harder than others.  In reality
column6: a large and growing portion of the super-rich have never broken a sweat. Their wealth has been handed to them.  The  rise of these two groups â€“ the working poor and non-working rich â€“ is  relatively new. Both are challenging the core American assumptions that  people are paid what theyâ€™re worth
column7: and work is justly rewarded. Why are these two groups growing? The ranks of the working poor are growing because wages at the bottom have dropped
column8: adjusted for inflation. With increasing numbers of Americans taking  low-paying jobs in retail sales
column15: the pay of the  bottom fifth is falling closer to the minimum wage. At the same time
column16: the real value of the federal minimum wage is lower today than it was a quarter century ago.  In addition
column17: most recipients of public assistance must now work in order to qualify.  Bill  Clintonâ€™s welfare reform of 1996 pushed the poor off welfare and into  work. Meanwhile
column20: has  emerged as the nationâ€™s largest anti-poverty program. Here
column22: having a  job is a prerequisite.  The new work requirements havenâ€™t reduced  the number or percentage of Americans in poverty. Theyâ€™ve just moved  poor people from being unemployed and impoverished to being employed and  impoverished. A very clever scheme by Republicans. While poverty declined in the early years of  welfare reform when the economy boomed and jobs were plentiful
column23: it began  growing in 2000. By 2012 it exceeded its level in 1996
column24: when welfare ended. At  the same time
column25: the ranks of the non-working rich have been swelling.  Americaâ€™s legendary â€œself-madeâ€ men and women are fast being replaced by  wealthy heirs.  Six of todayâ€™s ten wealthiest Americans are heirs  to prominent fortunes. The Walmart heirs alone have more wealth than  the bottom 40 percent of Americans combined. Americans  who became enormously wealthy over the last three decades are now  busily transferring that wealth to their children and grand children. The nation is on the cusp of the largest inter-generational transfer of wealth in history. A study  from the Boston College Center on Wealth and Philanthropy projects a  total of $59 trillion passed down to heirs between 2007 and 2061. As  the French economist Thomas Piketty reminds us
column26: this is the kind of  dynastic wealth thatâ€™s kept Europeâ€™s aristocracy going for centuries.  Itâ€™s about to become the major source of income for a new American  aristocracy. This is what the Koch/Walton Republicans have schemed for; the Gilded Age. The tax code encourages all this by favoring unearned income over earned income.  The  top tax rate paid by Americaâ€™s wealthy on their capital gains â€“ the  major source of income for the non-working rich â€“ has dropped from 33  percent in the late 1980s to 20 percent today
column27: putting it substantially  below the top tax rate on ordinary income (36.9 percent). If the owners of capital assets whose worth increases over their lifetime hold them until death
column28: their heirs pay zero capital gains taxes on them. Such â€œunrealizedâ€ gains now account for more than half the value of assets held by estates worth more than $100 million. At  the same time
column29: the estate tax has been slashed. Before George W. Bush  was president
column30: it applied to assets in excess of $2 million per couple  at a rate of 55 percent. Now it kicks in at $10
column33: at a  40 percent rate. Last year only 1.4 out of every 1
column35: and the effective rate they paid was only 17 percent. Republicans  now in control of Congress want to go even further. Last Friday the  Senate voted 54-46 in favor of a non-binding resolution to repeal the  estate tax altogether. Earlier in the week
column36: the House Ways and Means  Committee also voted for a repeal. The House is expected to vote in  coming weeks. Yet the specter of an entire generation doing  nothing for their money other than speed-dialing their wealth management  advisers is not particularly attractive. It puts more and more  responsibility for investing a substantial portion of the nationâ€™s  assets into the hands of people who have never worked. It also endangers our democracy
column37: as dynastic wealth inevitably and invariably accumulates political influence and power. Consider  the rise of both the working poor and the non-working rich
column38: and the  meritocratic ideal on which Americaâ€™s growing inequality is often  justified doesnâ€™t hold up. That widening inequality â€“ combined  with the increasing numbers of people who work full time but are still  impoverished and of others who have never worked and are fabulously  wealthy â€“ is undermining the moral foundations of American capitalism.  Just pointing out real quick that the moral foundation of American capitalism is enslaving human beings.  The actual info here is on point though. Organize! " False link
